utterances: Well, as I tell people, you know, the money might get you there, but the money doesn't keep you.
In a war zone or hostile environment, there's got to be more than just the dollar signs.
Well, Scott, thank you so much for talking to us.
Thank you, Michele.
Scott Schneider will soon return to Iraq, you know, once again, work for a private security firm.
No single government agency in the U.S.
tracks private contractors in Iraq.
Recent reporting by the L.A.
Times and New York Times puts the number at well over 100,000, and perhaps high enough to outnumber U.S.
troops in Iraq.
Tomorrow, we will continue our series.
We talk with Horatio Uretha(ph).
He's a political officer for the State Department based in Ramadi.
And you could find previous conversation at our Web site npr.org.
On Capitol Hill, there's a growing call for the resignation of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales.
Members of the Congress, including some Republicans, believe Gonzales have not been candid about why his Justice Department fired eight U.S.
attorneys.
With all the attention on Gonzales this week, we take a few moments now to look at the office of attorney general and the tension inherent within it.
Nancy Baker teaches government at New Mexico State University.
She joins me now from Las Cruces.
Welcome.
Thank you very much.
With your doctor, are you afraid that this will shorten your life?
...which you personally shun.
That's Simon Harrop of the advertising firm Brand Sense.
The company has teamed up with Britain's Royal Mail postal service to offer direct marketing which smell.
Lawmakers are reviewing the notes that the White House released about a call between President Trump and the president of Ukraine.
And the whistleblower complaint that started all of this has been turned over to the House Intelligence Committee.
It's now being reviewed by lawmakers on that panel.
NPR congressional correspondent Susan Davis is tracking the latest developments on Capitol Hill, and she joins us now.
Hi, Sue.
Hey, Ari.
Let's start with the reaction in Congress to these notes that were released by the White House today.
They confirm that the president did ask Ukraine's president to look into unsubstantiated accusations against Vice President Joe Biden and his son.
Trump also said he would direct his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani to be in touch.
What has the response from Congress been so far?
From Democrats, it certainly had a solidifying effect in that they believe that the path of an impeachment inquiry is the right one.
There's been even more Democrats who have come on board in support of impeachment today, lawmakers like Stephanie Murphy.
She's a Democrat from Florida and leads a moderate faction of Democrats up here on the Hill.
I've spoken to a ton of Democrats today.
One of them is Michigan Democrat Elissa Slotkin.
She was part of that group of freshman lawmakers who really sparked the impeachment cascade this week.
And this is what she told me.

We can't make it normal for the president of the United States of any party to go to a foreign leader - the Chinese, the North Koreans, let's go to the Iranians - anybody - and ask for dirt in our political process.
That should not be OK.
Slotkin is part of a group of lawmakers who have national security backgrounds.
She was a former CIA analyst.
She's also one of these freshmen from a really tough district.
It was a Republican-held seat.
And she's one of many Democrats I talked to today who said the political risks they're taking on are now worth it.
Now, what Pelosi announced yesterday was an impeachment inquiry.
Does today's response from Democrats lead lawmakers to believe that actual impeachment proceedings against Trump are more likely than before?
Yes, I think they are.
You know, lawmakers don't want to say it's going to happen for certain.
But here is House Intelligence chairman Adam Schiff.
He was asked that very question today, does this mean impeachment is inevitable?
He wouldn't say yes or no, but he did say this.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

No one should have any illusions about the seriousness of what is already uncontested, and that is the president of the United States has betrayed his oath of office and sacrificed our national security in doing so.
Betrayed his oath of office.
Yeah.
It's hard to hear that kind of language and not make the case that, today, the House has, indeed, moved closer towards moving on articles of impeachment against President Trump.
And so if they do move forward on that, is there any clarity about what exactly the charges would involve?
No, but there's a really interesting debate going on now inside the Democratic Party.
And there is a lot of Democrats who are saying impeachment should be - only be focused on this single issue.
One of those Democrats I talked to was Abigail Spanberger, another freshman, another freshman with a CIA background.
And she was asked this, and this is what she said.

The fact that there is so much confusion, even among members of Congress, about what if someone were to bring forward articles from all that's been done in all of these other committees, a lot of confusion exists over what those articles would be.
This is a very specific incident.

She said this incident, specifically because it's happening in real time, it involves a sitting president and involves an upcoming election, is much more clear of a case to make to the public than all the other issues Democrats have been looking at.
And just briefly, where are Republicans on this?
I know Senator Mitt Romney of Utah criticized the president today, but it doesn't sound like many others in the party are.
Not particularly.
The president has called on with his own allies.
They were meeting at the White House this morning with about a dozen lawmakers.
One of them was Congressman Mark Meadows.
I asked him if he thought there was a political risk here.
This is what he said.
I don't think so.
I - you can't help but read this thing - and I know it's supposed to be headlines and groundbreaking headlines.
You can't read this and say, oh, my gosh, much ado about nothing.
As you can hear, Republicans backing up the White House saying, simply, there's nothing to see here.
They don't seem to, as of now, think there will be a political risk for the president.
NPR congressional correspondent Susan Davis, thanks a lot.
You're welcome.
More than 400 firefighters answered the call when fire broke out in the Notre Dame Cathedral this Holy Week.
As Lieutenant Colonel Gabriel Plus, spokesperson for the Paris firefighters, told the Agence France-Presse, one doesn't imagine as a Paris firefighter one day intervening to save Notre Dame.
Time worked against us, he said.
The wind was against us, and we needed to retake control.
Father Jean-Marc Fournier, a fire department chaplain on the scene, told The New York Times artworks can be reproduced, while a human life can't.
But firefighters risked their lives to save the art and relics that have been kept in Notre Dame in a kind of trust for the world.
Father Fournier helped lead a group to the locked chest that held the crown of thorns said to have been worn by Jesus.
While Father Fournier searched for the keys to the chest, firefighters resorted to blunt force and broke it open.
A human chain of emergency workers delivered the crown to safety.
Gabriel Plus said, there is so much emotion and a little satisfaction to have been able to save what we were able to.
Yeah, exactly.
He was a CIA agent who was tasked with going to Iran and overthrowing the Mossadegh government and reinstating the shah or Iran's king.
May I ask you if you would take us back to the very first attorney general under George Washington, how did the founding fathers originally conceive of this position?
Well, actually they did have examples from British history of an attorney general, the king's attorney, and the attorney general during the colonial times.
But they really were divided on what it would look like.
In fact, the initial debates were should it be placed in - under the Supreme Court.
Should it be under the executive branch?
Finally, of course, they settled on it as an executive branch officer but it was created under the Judiciary Act of 1789.
And the first attorney general was part-time.
In fact, that was the case for the first 30 or 40 years, because it was felt that the attorneys general should maintain their skill level, I guess, by maintaining private practice.
There was not the sense that it was conflict of interest.
Mm-hmm.
Well, certainly in modern times it would seem as if the appointments have always had the potential for a divided loyalty.
On the one hand, an attorney general has to execute the policy, agenda of the president, the chief executives, and then on the other he or she must enforce the law.
Give me a good example of any attorney general pushing back against something the president might have wanted that person to do.
Well, for example, during the Lyndon Johnson administration, major plans were undertaken for a large protest, social justice protest at the White House.
You know, to set up a shantytown called Resurrection City across from the White House protesting the administration's failed war on poverty, and putting a lot of pressure on the White House.

Lyndon Johnson really wanted to deny the protesters the right to protest outside of the White House, and in fact, to closed down any possibility with the Natural Park Service of the establishment of the shantytown.
And his attorney general, Ramsey Clark, was very clear.
This is a First Amendment issue.
Nancy Baker, there was probably no more spectacular moment for the Office of Attorney General than Watergate.
When President Nixon ordered Attorney General Elliot Richardson to fire the special prosecutor Archibald Cox, Richardson refused to do so.
He then quit.
Then the deputy attorney general, William Ruckelshaus refused to fire the special prosecutor.
And it was such a chain of events.
Did people feel that that was, sort of, going to be the end of the office at that time?
Well, you know, that's a good question.
There were a lot of hearings held after Watergate to debate the issue, should the Justice Department be removed from White House control?
And the conclusion was that the problem was not systemic, it was not structural.
The problem was with the individuals appointed to the office and that, in fact, you want to have some political control.
This is a democracy.
You don't want to have the chief prosecutor of the country being able to operate without some sort of a democratic check and the president is that - ultimately the democratic check.
Right.
Well, we know what happened to that president.
